Blurb
Overview
This module is a pre-requisite for the following modules:
LIFE217
LIFE215
LIFE239
LIFE216
LIFE240

Skill/Other Attribute 1:
​Teamwork
How this is developed:
Work in pairs to produce a poster - must work as a team

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
​Problem solving skills
How this is developed:
Final examination questions

Skill/Other Attribute 3:​
Organisational skills
How this is developed:
Work in pairs to produce a poster - must do this independently

Skill/Other Attribute 4:
​Communication skills
How this is developed:
Work in pairs to produce a poster - must present poster at mini conference and answer questions

Skill/Other Attribute 5:
​Ethical awareness
How this is developed:
Lectures on animal ethics and welfare
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop knowledge and understanding of:

The present day structure of the agriculture industry including topics such as seasonality of production of the various domesticated animal species, the breeds used and which management  strategies are employed;

The role of various crops and crop by-products as food sources; their evaluation as suitable foods for animals; how the nutritional requirements of animals are met;  and how to assess and formulate rations to prevent poor performance, metabolic disease and toxicities.

Introductory theory of practical animal breeding; and to apply, evaluate and interpret problems in veterinary animal husbandry.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides an introduction to veterinary animal husbandry in the form of lectures, a workshop on poster presentation and a mini conference where students exhibit their posters.

The module covers the basic physiology relevant to animal management; environmental considerations, nutrition and housing; the welfare of managed animals and breeding issues.

The module is assessed by continuous assessment, the poster, and online tests.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory physiology:

Basic physiology covering reproduction, digestion (simple stomached, fore-gut / hind-gut fermenter), homeostasis. To enable understanding of animal management and husbandry aspects.  


Environment, nutrition & housing:

The present-day role and structure of the agricultural industry in the UK;

The seasonality of the production cycle and the interaction between crop and animal production;

The core nutrients, and design and formulation of diets;

The causes of metabolic conditions and toxicities;

How animals grow and develop and the factors that influence these processes;

Animal responses to changes in the climatic environment and how this impacts on the design of animal housing, and production efficiency;

Typical production cycles and management practices in the UK.


Welfare:

Animal behaviour relevant to addressing problems of husbandry and welfare associated with captive husbandry of managed animals;

The meaning of animal welfare and importance of the Brambell Report and the Farm Animal Welfare Committee;

The “Five Freedoms” and the use of behaviour to understand welfare.


Breeding:

Introduction to common breeding practices employed in the UK livestock sectors.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, PBL, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 - E-Lecture
Description: Two 1 hour lectures will be delivered online synchronously each week. >25% of the time will be dedicated to active student participation.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students shall be directed to reading materials to supplement lectures

Teaching Method 2 - Online tutorial
Description: Online synchronous session, a single 2h session.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students will learn about poster presentation and will be encouraged to decide their own topic relevant to animal husbandry, research this and produce a poster

Teaching Method 3 - Online MCQs
Description: Formative revision MCQ
Attendance Recorded: No
Notes: Revision MCQs will be provided online during the module

Teaching Method 4 - other
Description: Student Mini Conference, taking place online. 2h.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Student mini conference where their posters will be virtually exhibited

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students write produce a poster which will prepare them for interviews and conferences.

Assessment 1: Assessment 1 is a poster presentation. Students will complete this activity in a group. Anonymous marking for this assessment is not possible.
Maps with LO 1,2,3,4 and S1,3,4

Assessment 2: Assessment 2 will be an online test consisting of multiple choice and similar question styles.
Maps with LO 1,2,3,4 and S2,5

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Describe the role of the agricultural industry in the UK and to explain the seasonality of the production cycle and the interaction between crop and animal production and to identify the industries that pertain to a variety of farm and companion animal species.
 LO2 ​Demonstrate how to assess and formulate nutritional rations and describe the causes of metabolic conditions and toxicities;
 LO3 ​Define how animals grow, develop and breed, and the factors that influence these processes, such as inherited diseases;
 LO4 ​Explain an animal's responses to changes in the climatic environment and how these influence efficiency and productivity outcomes.

Blurb
Overview
This module is a pre-requisite for the following modules:
LIFE217
LIFE215
LIFE239
LIFE216
LIFE240

Skill/Other Attribute 1:
​Teamwork
How this is developed:
Work in pairs to produce a poster - must work as a team

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
​Problem solving skills
How this is developed:
Final examination questions

Skill/Other Attribute 3:​
Organisational skills
How this is developed:
Work in pairs to produce a poster - must do this independently

Skill/Other Attribute 4:
​Communication skills
How this is developed:
Work in pairs to produce a poster - must present poster at mini conference and answer questions

Skill/Other Attribute 5:
​Ethical awareness
How this is developed:
Lectures on animal ethics and welfare
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop knowledge and understanding of:

The present day structure of the agriculture industry including topics such as seasonality of production of the various domesticated animal species, the breeds used and which management  strategies are employed;

The role of various crops and crop by-products as food sources; their evaluation as suitable foods for animals; how the nutritional requirements of animals are met;  and how to assess and formulate rations to prevent poor performance, metabolic disease and toxicities.

Introductory theory of practical animal breeding; and to apply, evaluate and interpret problems in veterinary animal husbandry.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides an introduction to veterinary animal husbandry in the form of lectures, a workshop on poster presentation and a mini conference where students exhibit their posters.

The module covers the basic physiology relevant to animal management; environmental considerations, nutrition and housing; the welfare of managed animals and breeding issues.

The module is assessed by continuous assessment, the poster, and online tests.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory physiology:

Basic physiology covering reproduction, digestion (simple stomached, fore-gut / hind-gut fermenter), homeostasis. To enable understanding of animal management and husbandry aspects.  


Environment, nutrition & housing:

The present-day role and structure of the agricultural industry in the UK;

The seasonality of the production cycle and the interaction between crop and animal production;

The core nutrients, and design and formulation of diets;

The causes of metabolic conditions and toxicities;

How animals grow and develop and the factors that influence these processes;

Animal responses to changes in the climatic environment and how this impacts on the design of animal housing, and production efficiency;

Typical production cycles and management practices in the UK.


Welfare:

Animal behaviour relevant to addressing problems of husbandry and welfare associated with captive husbandry of managed animals;

The meaning of animal welfare and importance of the Brambell Report and the Farm Animal Welfare Committee;

The “Five Freedoms” and the use of behaviour to understand welfare.


Breeding:

Introduction to common breeding practices employed in the UK livestock sectors.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, PBL, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 - E-Lecture
Description: Two 1 hour lectures will be delivered online synchronously each week. >25% of the time will be dedicated to active student participation.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students shall be directed to reading materials to supplement lectures

Teaching Method 2 - Online tutorial
Description: Online synchronous session, a single 2h session.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students will learn about poster presentation and will be encouraged to decide their own topic relevant to animal husbandry, research this and produce a poster

Teaching Method 3 - Online MCQs
Description: Formative revision MCQ
Attendance Recorded: No
Notes: Revision MCQs will be provided online during the module

Teaching Method 4 - other
Description: Student Mini Conference, taking place online. 2h.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Student mini conference where their posters will be virtually exhibited

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students write produce a poster which will prepare them for interviews and conferences.

Assessment 1: Assessment 1 is a poster presentation. Students will complete this activity in a group. Anonymous marking for this assessment is not possible.
Maps with LO 1,2,3,4 and S1,3,4

Assessment 2: Assessment 2 will be an online test consisting of multiple choice and similar question styles.
Maps with LO 1,2,3,4 and S2,5

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO2 ​Demonstrate how to assess and formulate nutritional rations and describe the causes of metabolic conditions and toxicities;
 LO3 ​Define how animals grow, develop and breed, and the factors that influence these processes, such as inherited diseases;
 LO4 ​Explain an animal's responses to changes in the climatic environment and how these influence efficiency and productivity outcomes.
